meta.title: Parenting From Your Heart
meta.subtitle: Apply Nonviolent Communication (NVC) principles to shift from power-over to power-with parenting.

why_matters.text: Parenting based on 'power-over' (coercion, rewards, punishment) creates resistance and disconnection. Parenting based on 'power-with' (collaboration, mutual needs) cultivates intrinsic motivation and deep connection. NVC principles resolve conflicts by addressing the underlying needs of both the child and the parent.

analysis.heading: 1. Needs vs. Strategies
analysis.intro_text: A Need is universal (safety, rest, play, connection). A Strategy is a specific action to meet a need (watching TV, hitting a sibling, refusing to eat). Conflict happens at the level of Strategy. If parents identify the underlying Need, new strategies can always be found.

insight_card.title: The Real Issue
insight_card.text: Most conflicts are not about the behavior itself but about the underlying need. When the need is met, the behavior shifts.

analysis.heading: 2. Hearing the "Yes" Behind the "No"
analysis.intro_text: When a child says 'No' to a request, they are saying 'Yes' to a different need. The parent's job is not to crush the 'No,' but to find the 'Yes' and integrate it.

insight_card.title: The Deeper Yes
insight_card.text: Resistance always points to an unmet need. Finding the need allows collaboration instead of power struggle.

analysis.heading: 3. Protective vs. Punitive Force
analysis.intro_text: NVC allows for force, but only protective force. Punitive force intends to cause pain; protective force intends only to prevent injury. The difference is in the parent's intention and energy.

insight_card.title: Clear Intention
insight_card.text: Children can sense whether force comes from care (safety) or punishment (revenge). The intention is everything.

analysis.heading: 4. Moving Beyond Praise
analysis.intro_text: Conventional praise ('Good job!') is judgmentâ€”a 'positive' judgment, but still judgment. It fosters extrinsic motivation. Appreciation ('I felt relieved when you cleaned up because I value order') fosters intrinsic motivation.

insight_card.title: Intrinsic Worth
insight_card.text: When children act because they understand how their actions meet real needs, they develop intrinsic motivation that lasts.

actions.title: The 4-Step NVC Conflict Resolution
actions.context: Use to solve problems without coercion by addressing both needs equally.

steps.description: State facts without judgment: 'I see a backpack in the hall' (NOT 'You are messy').
State your emotion: 'I feel frustrated...'
Connect to your value: '...because I have a need for order and ease in the morning.'
Ask for a specific action: 'Would you be willing to put it on the hook?'
If they say no, decode their need (see Process 2 below) rather than insisting.

actions.title: Decoding the "No"
actions.context: Use when the child refuses your request to find the unmet need and collaborate.

steps.description: Don't react to the 'defiance.' Breathe.
'It sounds like you have a reason for saying no. Can you tell me?'
'Are you saying no because you want to keep playing (Need: Play)?' or 'Do you want to decide for yourself (Need: Autonomy)?'
'I hear you. You really want to choose.'
'I have a need for us to leave on time. Is there a way we can meet your need for play AND my need for punctuality?'

actions.title: The Self-Empathy Pause
actions.context: Use to regulate yourself before engaging the child, breaking reactive cycles.

steps.description: You feel anger or the urge to yell. Pause.
Step away physically or mentally. Create space.
'What is going on in me? I am angry.'
'Why? Because I am exhausted and I have a desperate need for rest/support.'
Acknowledging the need often lowers the intensity immediately.
Address the child from this place of self-knowledge, not reactive rage.

actions.title: From Praise to Appreciation
actions.context: Use to build intrinsic self-worth and show children the real impact of their actions.

steps.description: The child did something helpful. Pause before responding.
Swallow the words 'Good job.'
'You shared your toy with your sister.'
'I felt so happy watching that.'
'Because I really value kindness in our family.'
The child feels seen and valued, not just evaluated.
